VISUALFORCE B2B COMMERCE
Provide a Smooth Path to Purchase for Storefront Buyers

Give a buyer an intuitive, trusted experience as they create a shopping cart, check out, confirm an order, and generate an invoice. As admin, you have several options for configuring different parts of the purchase experience to satisfy your project's requirements. You can define the experience for both guest and registered buyers, including restricting guest buyers from certain functionality.

REQUIRED EDITIONS

Salesforce Compatibility

Salesforce Classic (not available in all orgs) and Lightning Experience for Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.




B2B Commerce Compatibility

B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’20 (version 4.12)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’19 (version 4.11)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’19 (version 4.10)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’18 (version 4.9)
Considerations for Supporting a Buyer's Cart Experience
Provide a trusted experience for your buyers as they build a cart and prepare to purchase from your storefront. Learn more about your options for helping buyers add products to their cart, view their cart, manage multiple carts, and manage carts with a large number of items.
Allow a Buyer to Create a Wish List of Items for a Future Cart
Equip buyers with tools for planning their upcoming purchases. When you enable wish lists, a buyer can add products to a wish list instead of their active cart. Later, the buyer can convert the wish list to an active cart, and continue with checkout. As admin, you can also create a read-only wish list, which essentially provides a cart template that a buyer can clone.
Email a Buyer for an Abandoned Cart
Keep your buyers engaged with your brand and motivated to complete their purchase. When a buyer adds products to their cart but doesn't complete checkout, you can automatically email the buyer and entice them to return. By combining email templates, email alerts, and Process Builder, you can easily develop an automated message that references data directly from the buyer's cart.
Enforce Quantity Rules When a Buyer Adds Products to a Cart or Wish List
To require buyers to order specific quantities of products from your storefront, you can define product quantity rules. A buyer can successfully add items to the cart only when the buyer specifies a valid quantity that satisfies your defined increment requirements.
Set Product Prices in the Cart from an External Source
For an organization that has data in multiple systems, you can avoid data duplication and integrate your storefront's price data with external systems. The B2B Commerce for Visualforce cart API provides extension points for passing a product's name, SKU, and price information from an external source. With these capabilities and a little custom development, you can integrate dynamic price changes or apply budget, payment, or approval workflows to the default cart and checkout functionality.
Allow a B2B Commerce for Visualforce Guest Buyer to Maintain a Cart
Because a guest buyer hasn't registered for a storefront account, they can't access the My Account page and manage any carts they've created. If a guest buyer begins creating a cart, but then closes the browser tab where their storefront session was active, the cart becomes abandoned. When the buyer returns to the storefront later, they start over with a new, empty cart. To provide a more positive experience, you can ensure that the guest buyer inherits the same cart ID when they return in a later browser session.
Allow a B2B Commerce for Visualforce Guest Buyer to Check Out
By default, B2B Commerce for Visualforce requires a guest buyer to register for a storefront account before they can check out. To allow a guest buyer to check out without registering for a storefront account, set up the appropriate Visualforce page, custom object, and Apex class permissions.
Standard Checkout versus Line-Level Independence (LLI) Checkout
When a buyer is ready to place an order, B2B Commerce for Visualforce provides two workflow options for the buyer to complete checkout. Set up the workflow that supports that your organization's fulfillment and shipping capabilities.
Calculate Tax at Checkout
Ensure that your storefront complies with federal and local regulations for collecting sales tax. B2B Commerce for Visualforce provides a default object for defining simple tax rates for US states or Canadian provinces. By default, B2B Commerce for Visualforce calculates the cart's tax based on a shipping address and the included products.
Set Up Payment Types for Storefront Purchases
Provide the payment workflow that your buyers expect or that your organization requires. By default, B2B Commerce for Visualforce supports only purchase order (PO) payments, which you can relate to an invoice attached to the account. With some manual setup and extension, you can optionally support other methods of payment—including credit cards, bank accounts, and so on.
Fulfill a Buyer's Order
By default, B2B Commerce for Visualforce creates records of its order-related custom objects after a buyer completes checkout. B2B Commerce also provides some default order confirmation and order management resources for buyers. However, fulfilling an order—processing and shipment—requires integration with another system.
Scale Your Cart Capabilities for a Large Number of Items
Cart Scale is a collection of capabilities that work together to support carts and orders that contain a large number of items. Balance storefront performance and buyer experience as you give buyers new tools for effectively scaling the size of their carts.
Enable Asynchronous Order Placement for Checkout
Provide a better experience for a buyer who places an order from a cart that contains a large number of items. You can optionally process orders asynchronously. Asynchronous processing waits for the appropriate resources to become available and executes the order placement logic in the background so that the buyer can complete other tasks on the storefront.
Considerations for Asynchronous Processing for Carts and Orders
Asynchronous Apex jobs for pricing a cart and placing an order can help you deliver a better storefront experience in some cases. As with all things, there are some caveats and tradeoffs to consider before you determine the scope of your asynchronous activity.
Generate an Invoice for a Buyer's Order
If your storefront allows buyers to complete checkout with only a purchase order or other form of promised payment, ensure that the buyers complete their payment responsibilities to your storefront. You can generate an invoice after a buyer places an order, and provide self-service tools for the buyer to manage their invoices from the My Account page. An invoice can represent either a debit—a bill for payment—or credit—an amount of funds returned to the buyer's account. You can also roll up multiple individual invoices into a single summary or parent invoice.
